unnormalised: Okay, folks, let's talk traffic – specifically, traffic regulations, Indian style! If you’re a driver in India, from bustling Mumbai to serene Kerala, you know the 'rules of the road' can be... well, let's just say 'flexible'. But hey, that doesn’t mean they don't exist!
normalised: Okay, folks, let's talk traffic – specifically, traffic regulations, Indian style! If you're a driver in India, from bustling Mumbai to serene Kerala, you know the 'rules of the road' can be... well, let's just say 'flexible'. But hey, that doesn’t mean they don't exist!

unnormalised: First things first, you gotta have your documents in order. License, registration, insurance – the whole shebang. Forget your RC book and you might be chatting with a friendly (or not-so-friendly) traffic constable near, say, Juhu beach. And that chat usually ends with a hole burned in your wallet in the form of a fine (Rs. 500 or maybe more, depending on his mood!).

unnormalised: Then there are the unspoken rules. Like, honking isn't an expression of anger, it's a friendly "Hey, I'm here!". Or the 'lane discipline' which is more of a suggestion than a hard and fast rule. But trust me, following the actual rules, like sticking to the speed limit (usually around 60 km/h on highways) can save you a whole lot of trouble. Especially since those speed cameras are popping up everywhere these days.

unnormalised: Parking? Oh, parking is an art form. You need to be a master strategist to squeeze your Maruti Suzuki into a space that's approximately the size of your average living room in a Mumbai chawl (maybe 100 sq ft?). And watch out for 'No Parking' zones – Dr. Sharma found out the hard way that even flashing your "Doctor" sign doesn't always get you out of a ticket in Connaught Place!

unnormalised: Finally, always wear your seatbelt (duh!) and please, for the love of Ganesha, don't drink and drive. It's not worth the risk to yourself or anyone else. Driving in India can be chaotic, but if we all try to follow the rules (and maybe be a little more patient), it can be a whole lot safer for everyone from Delhi to Dimapur. And remember, a little bit of chai and some "adjusting" (you know what I mean!) can sometimes help smooth things over with the traffic police. Just sayin'!
